newsitem.title: UK: ROYAL BANK SCOTLAND BUYS MORTGAGE LENDER.
newsitem.headline: ROYAL BANK SCOTLAND BUYS MORTGAGE LENDER.

text.p: Royal Bank of Scotland said Wednesday it agreed to buy one of Britain's biggest mortgage lenders, Birmingham Midshires, for 605 million to 630 million pounds ($956 million to $995 million).
The bank said the deal would make it Britain's tenth-largest mortgage lender managing residential mortgage assets of 12 billion pounds ($18.9 billion).
It said the acquisition, expected to be completed in the second half of 1998, would have a neutral effect on earnings per share in the first year and be earnings enhancing thereafter.
Royal Bank planned to finance the acquisition without recourse to an equity issue to shareholders.
"The deal creates many new business opportunities, building on the respective skills and product expertise of each organization," Royal Bank Chief Executive George Mathewson said in a statement.
Birmingham Midshires agreed to the deal after a strategic review of its options following the flotation of some of Britain's biggest mutually held mortgage lenders, known here as building societies.
Birmingham will operate as a separate business within Royal Bank, with existing management in place for at least three years after completion of the deal.

Birmingham Midshires, with branches concentrated in central, northwest and southwest England, had residential mortgage assets under management of 6.1 billion pounds ($9.6 billion) and retail deposits of 4.5 billion ($7.1 billion) at the end of 1996.
